You should be expecting us - I’m Mr. Hardy, and this is my very dear friend Mr. Laurel. The RECEPTIONIST is about to burst.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: You just wait ‘til I tell me mam it’s you! We never get anybody famous stayin’ here - to be honest I thought you'd retired! HARDY takes the pen from it’s holder and with an extravag flourish signs in to the register.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: No no, we may be getting old but we’re not done yet.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: You know, I’m so old now I walked into an antique shop the other day and they bought me.  Stan and Ollie - Blue Revisions 24.03.17 16 The RECEPTIONIST laughs.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: He’s exaggerating, of course. But we've come a long way since our first job, selling hot dogs at Custer’s Last Stand.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: All me family loves your films - where are yous gonna be appearin’ then - the Theatre Royal?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: No it’s... He’s forgotten the name - LAUREL answers for him:

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: The Queen’s Hall.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: (Surprised) Queen’s Hall? That can’t be right. All the big stars play at the Theatre Royal. That’s where you’1ll be playing.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I’m sure you’re right. (to Laurel) It is the Theatre Royal?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: No, It’s the Queen’s Hall. A few moments of uncomfortable silence. RECEPTIONIST (cont'd) Well never mind, here’s your room keys. She hands LAUREL and HARDY their keys.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Thank you. (Looks round expectantly) Is there a Bell Boy please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no Bell Boys. LAUREL and HARDY struggle along a corridor to their rooms, HARDY - now with the golf clubs his shoulder - dragging his heavy trunk behind him. LAURE stops by his door and, as he unlocks it, turns to HARDY w is in the room opposite.  Stan and Ollie - Blue Revisions 24.03.17 16A

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: My room in ten minutes? HARDY looks at him, aghast. He still wants to work tonigh LAUREL (cont'd) I thought we could run some lines?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: (Barely concealed sarcasm) Sure. Why not.  10 11 12 Stan and Ollie - Blue Revisions 24.03.17 17 HARDY opens the door to his room and enters. INT. HARDY’S BEDROOM, NEWCASTLE GUEST HOUSE - NIGHT 9

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARDY struggles in with his luggage. He turns the light o and surveys the room: shabby and uninviting, a tatty, candlewick bedspread on the bed. He goes to haul the trun onto his bed, but it pops open and a huge cache of tinned food - ham, peaches, potatoes, corned beef, which were on of his clothes - tumbles out and rolls all over the floor HARDY sighs heavily.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Oh death where is thy sting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow light spills from a curtained, upper storey window Over this we hear, SFX the clack clack of a typewriter. INT. LAUREL’S ROOM, NEWCASTLE GUEST HOUSE - NIGHT 11

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A meagre coal fire glows in the grate as LAUREL, puffing cigarette, taps at a battered portable typewriter by the light of a table lamp. A pot of tea and a plate of dog ea sandwiches has been set out on a coffee table. He pauses, pulls the typed page from the typewriter and reads it bac INT. JOE SCHENCK’S OFFICE - DAY [FLASHBACK] 12

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CLOSE UP of a contract, the logo of ‘Twentieth Century at the top of the page. It’s 1938 and we REVEAL LAUREL on a chair, an empty one n to him, flicking through the contract. He is in the luxur office of executive Joe SCHENCK, late 50s. Surrounded by panelling, leather, and portraits of stars of the day - S Henje, Betty Grable, Spencer Tracey, Tyrone Power -— LAUR feels uncomfortable, out of place. The man next to him is obviously his lawyer (round glasses, 40s, curly hair slic back) and LAUREL hands him the contract. LAUREL is acutel aware that he is keeping SCHENCK waiting; he catches him looking at his watch and tries a smile which is not retur

dialogues.speaker: SCHENCK
dialogues.text: You sure he wants to do this Stan? I mean, Fox would love to have you here, but...

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: This is what we’ve both been waiting for Joe. I can’t imagine what’s held him up.

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: Why doesn’t Stanley sign, then all we have to do is have Oliver sign when he gets here.  13 Stan and Ollie - Blue Revisions 24.03.17 18

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: (Taking out his pen) That’s a good idea, isn’t it Joe? SCHENCK - who is quickly losing patience - doesn’t respon The LAWYER hands LAUREL the contract back and LAUREL hand him the pen. LAUREL realises he needs the pen and takes i back from the LAWYER, giving him the contract at the same time. Is it genuine confusion, or a little bit of busines LAUREL takes pen and contract back from his LAWYER and si next to his name, leaving Hardy’s blank. He looks up, tri another smile with SCHENCK - again, not returned. We hear HARDY’S voice under this:

dialogues.speaker: HARDY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I wish I was there with you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to 1953. HARDY is using the hotel telephone to make transatlantic call to his wife:

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: (Dreamily) «+. sitting out the back, watching the sun go down.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What’s the hotel like?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: It’s like a castle, set in the countryside, beautiful grounds... (Warming to it) «+. which go down to a lake, with a little stone bridge over it. The RECEPTIONIST returns to the desk from a back office. HARDY, a little embarrassed, gives her a polite smile.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Are you getting enough to eat?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: The staff lay out little sweetmeats and pastries wherever we turn. Everyone’s so happy to see us touring again we’re being treated like kings.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ida and I received our tickets today so we’re just as excited as can be.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I am too, and this...  14 Stan and Ollie - Blue Revisions 24.03.17 19 He sees the NIGHT PORTER is watching him so turns away- HARDY (cont'd) -is for you, with all my love- -kisses his finger tips and blows the kiss down the phone

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I love you too Oliver, you know I do. (Beat, slight edge in her voice) So... how are things with Stanley?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Oh... you know Stan.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: How has he been towards you? On HARDY, thoughtful for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARDY, serious expression, walks on set wearing a dark su but carrying an unfamiliar top hat.

dialogues.speaker: HAL ROACH
dialogues.text: Babe! Where have you been? You had me worried for a minute there... He gives a (plainly uncomfortable) HARDY a bear hug. HAL ROACH (cont'd) What the hell, you’re here now. You’re both here. He gestures and HARDY looks across to someone with his ba to us, also wearing a dark suit and top hat, being given last check over by a MAKE-UP LADY. From his build we assu it must be Laurel. HARDY takes position next to an ELEPHA with a hot water bottle bandaged to its head. The set is wooden barn scattered with bales of hay, and he’s playing vet treating a sick circus elephant. As he sits on a stoo LUCILLE, carrying a clip board, stops by to reassure him:

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Mr. Hardy, everything alright?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: You know, first day of school Mrs. Hardy. I’m glad you’re here. Do you think it’s going to be ok?

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: It’s just a movie Babe.  Stan and Ollie - Blue Revisions 24.03.17 20 She squeezes his hand then carries on to her position (as script supervisor) next to the director GORDON DOUGLAS, w is younger than Horne and less assured in his manner. A WRANGLER hands HARDY a mallet and gives him some last min instructions - though HARDY looks totally preoccupied:

dialogues.speaker: WRANGLER
dialogues.text: (Patting the elephant) When you touch her knee with the Mallet, she’ll lift her leg like you’re checking her reflexes. ROACH calls over:

dialogues.speaker: ROACH
dialogues.text: You wanna go for one you two? HARDY looks over again to ‘LAUREL’, and now, as he turns, see that he’s... not Laurel. It is in fact HARRY LANGDON, Laurel look-alike, who is playing the elephant’s owner. LANGDON is of similar build to Laurel and wears the same pancake white make up.

dialogues.speaker: LANGDON
dialogues.text: Ready when you are Babe. We now see that this is Roach’s attempt at a new partners just with different hats. LANGDON comes over and stands n to HARDY. He puts his hand lightly on HARDY’S shoulder (a he involuntarily stiffens at the touch). As he looks arou HARDY becomes aware that various CREW MEMBERS, who have worked on Laurel & Hardy films, are avoiding eye contact him as they go about their work.

dialogues.speaker: ROACH
dialogues.text: This is great, you and Harry are gonna be just great together. HARDY looks at LANGDON, who spreads his hands and gives h blank smile, exactly as Laurel would. HARDY returns a pol smile, but we can see he’s uncomfortable - that he can’t escape the feeling he’s betraying Stan. He looks to LUCIL who tries to encourage him with a smile.  15 Stan and Ollie - Locked White Shooting Script 22.02.17 21

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Okay let’s roll camera... He gets the response ‘Rolling’ from sound and camera. On HARDY, suppressing a sinking feeling: DOUGLAS (cont'd) Aaand - action! ROACH, over-excited, shouts out simultaneously:

dialogues.speaker: ROACH
dialogues.text: Action! INT. LAUREL’S ROOM, NEWCASTLE GUEST HOUSE - NIGHT 15

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A closed door. SFX KNOCKING from outside. LAUREL, who has been frowning in concentration, looks up:

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Just a minute! He quickly stubs his cigarette out and wafts away the smo hides the ashtray in the bin, then unlocks the door to HA who sniffs theatrically, looks at LAUREL suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Do you realise what you've done? A beat, then LAUREL - going along with it for fun - nods miserably. HARDY enters and turns to LAUREL: HARDY (cont'd) Well, come on - out with them. LAUREL takes a packet of Chesterfield cigarettes from his inside pocket and HARDY snatches it off him. He takes one then offers the pack to LAUREL who also takes one. HARDY produces a lighter and they both light up and take deep puffs, HARDY putting the pack back in his pocket. HARDY (cont'd) Now isn’t that better? Sharing? LAUREL nods, big smile on his face. HARDY (cont'd) And here’s something else we’re not supposed to have. He produces a half bottle of Scotch from inside his jacke LAUREL rustles up a couple of cups and HARDY pours them e a large measure. HARDY (cont'd) For medicinal purposes... They clink cups together and the ‘skit’ ends.  Stan and Ollie - Pink Revisions 17.03.17 22 HARDY (cont'd) I’m getting a sinking feeling about this place. Did you see her face when we told her what theatre we were playing?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: It'll be fine, Queen’s Hall is a good theatre.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Well we gotta make sure we’re in nicer hotels when the girls arrive.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: I‘1l get onto it. HARDY crosses to the window to peer out into the murky ni with a shiver.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: You heard from Muffin? LAUREL starts to correct his script by hand.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Miffin.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Miffin. Is that really his name? Has he given you our shooting dates yet?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: I’m waitin’ on a call. HARDY lets the curtain drop and sits down in one of two e chairs by the fireside - his leg causing him some pain as lowers himself. He picks up his cup of Scotch, takes a si LAUREL (cont'd) What do you think about this for a title: ‘Rob ‘Em Good’. You know, playin’ off ‘Robin Hood’? There was a picture used that in the 20s but nobody would remember by now. During this HARDY takes a sandwich from the plate on the coffee table, peels back the top and looks suspiciously a the filling smeared inside, wrinkling his nose as he snif

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: What is this stuff? LAUREL takes one, bites into it.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Fish paste. It’s the war rationing. Stan and Ollie - Locked White Shooting Script 22.02.17 2

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Still? (LAUREL shrugs) Explains why they looked at me like I was nuts when I asked for an egg sandwich. HARDY looks at LAUREL, already making corrections to the he’s just typed with his pen as he flicks through his wor HARDY (cont'd) ‘Rob ‘Em Good’. I like that Stan. HARDY takes another sip of his Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: I been workin’ on this scene for the movie where we go into the castle to rescue Maid Marian, and we're hiding behind this curtain- HARDY decides hunger has got the better of him and - afte liberally sprinkling salt over the filling - tries the sandwich. LAUREL starts to giggle as he tells the story. LAUREL (cont'd) -and the guards are lookin’ for us-— He’s really making himself laugh as he tells the story - it’s infectious. HARDY starts to chuckle too - even thoug doesn’t know the punchline. LAUREL (cont'd) -and, I'll show you, turn around... HARDY turns round; we stay on him as we hear some rustlin LAUREL (OOV) (cont'd) Okay... HARDY turns back and sees LAUREL’S shoes poking out from beneath the curtains in his room. LAUREL (OOV) (cont'd) (From behind curtain) Now you stab me with your sword- HARDY looks about, picks up a shoe horn and, getting into character-

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: A-ha! A-ha! So you think you can play that game do you - well you can’t hide from me! -uses it to stab the curtain at about chest height.  16 Stan and Ollie - Locked White Shooting Script 22.02.17 24

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: And then you pull the curtain back, and... HARDY pulls the curtain back and there is LAUREL on his knees, below where the ‘sword’ went in to the curtain, kneeling on his shoes like Toulouse-Lautrec, looking at himself in a dressing mirror opposite. He looks so ridicu that HARDY howls with laughter - which makes LAUREL laugh even harder. LAUREL (cont'd) Isn't that silly! HARDY pulls his shoes off and - with some painful gruntin lowers himself to kneel on them the same as LAUREL. Now they’re both doing it - getting a little hysterical with laughter as they look at themselves in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Now I’m down here - I can’t get up again! This sets them both off again. LAUREL tries to get up-

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Neither can I! (Gasping for air) We're stuck! We go OUT on the boys, howling with laughter at themselve the mirror. EXT. QUEEN’S HALL THEATRE - DAY 16 A grey day, the rain falling. A provincial English theatr small and shabby - Hardy’s sinking feeling was spot on. A OLD MAN passes, oblivious, as a WORKMAN pastes up a poste Bernard Delfont Presents The Personal Visit Of Hollywood’s Greatest Comedy Couple Stan LAUREL & Oliver HARDY Under this we hear the incredulous voice of Stan’s wife I

dialogues.speaker: IDA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -you stay in guest house? You should be in best hotel.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, beggars can’t be choosers can they my darling.  Stan and Ollie - Green Revisions 11.04.17 25

dialogues.speaker: IDA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Why are you not play West End? I don’t like this Delfont. As the shot TRACKS we see LAUREL in a public phone box ne to the theatre, on a transatlantic call:

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Ida, he’s put this tour together for us, and we didn’t exactly have too many other offers did we? Anyway, we got the movie to look forward to. He glances at the little Queen’s Hall Theatre outside. LAUREL (cont'd) Okay the theatre is a little on the small side, but that means it’1l be easier to sell it out.

dialogues.speaker: IDA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: How is Oliver - is he pulling weight?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: He’s doing fine. (Quickly moves on) Tell me all the news. How are the ducks?

dialogues.speaker: IDA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, I try to get them into duck house at night but- The pips sound, he has to quickly insert more coins.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Hello? Ida?

dialogues.speaker: IDA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Stanley?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Oh thank goodness, I thought I’d lost you. He looks glumly at the rain spattering against the window the phone box... LAUREL (cont'd) I just wanted to tell you how much I’m missing you, and how cold the bed is without you.  17 Stan and Ollie - Locked White Shooting Script 22.02.17 26

dialogues.speaker: IDA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I am missing you too. I am trying not to cry each night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opening night. LAUREL and HARDY are in costume, preparing go on. HARDY sits himself on a hospital bed and a stage h (BILLY BRADY, 20s) encases his leg in an oversized plaste cast. LAUREL glances through a crack in the curtain and, worried, sees the house is barely half full. BRADY attach cable to HARDY’S plaster cast and starts to hoist it up l it’s in traction. BRADY glances over to LAUREL and sees h going through his pre-show ritual of checking his cuffs a held in place by paper clips, and that there are no heels his boots. BRADY plucks up the courage to talk to him:

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: You worked with my grandad Mr. Laurel. LAUREL looks up at him. BRADY (cont'd) He told me how you never have heels on your boots, to make you walk funny.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Your grandad?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Billy Brady, I was named after him. LAUREL looks at him. BRADY does a wide-eyed, goofy smile a camp flutter of his hands. BRADY (cont'd) ‘Billy Brady - He’s No Lady’? Suddenly the mists part, and LAUREL realises who this man

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Oh my goodness, it’s like staring straight into the past! (Shakes his hand warmly) You're Billy’s grandson... he was a wonderful comic. Very funny drag act.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: (To HARDY) He always said, Mr. Hardy, that Stan were obsessed with his comedy. Never stopped working on his act - even though he reckoned in them days it were crap.  18 Stan and Ollie - Green Revisions 11.04.17 27

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Nothing much has changed there Billy. BRADY laughs - so does LAUREL.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: He was a very good friend of mine your grandad was - how is he?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Oh, he passed away a few years ago. LAUREL seems very moved by this.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry to hear that. The STAGE MANAGER comes out to give them all a heads up:

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: Curtain up in one minute Stan? LAUREL nods his okay.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: He was on stage right up ‘til the end. Did a panto the night before he died. HARDY listens to this as BRADY wheels his bed to centre stage. LAUREL takes a position in the wings and BRADY now comes over and hands him a paper bag and a bunch of flowe BRADY (cont'd) He was very weak but he was determined to get through it. This seems to hit home with LAUREL who, as the lights dim falls quiet. He looks to HARDY, alone in bed in the backs gloom. INT. QUEEN’S HALL THEATRE, NEWCASTLE - NIGHT 18

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There’s a buzz of expectation out front, then the orchest strikes up ‘The Dance Of The Cuckoos’, Laurel & Hardy's instantly recognisable theme tune. LAUREL looks across to HARDY and they exchange that same nod. Then, stage lights curtain open, and loud applause as the audience sees HARD stage in the bed. LAUREL silently counts in his head, the LAUREL strides on stage to another round of warm applause clutching the bunch of flowers and paper bag, blank expression. The sketch begins:

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Hi Ollie, how are you?  Stan and Ollie - Green Revisions 11.04.17 27A

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Never mind how I am - what took you so long to get here?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Well they said no visitors so I said I was your son and it worked like a charm.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: My son! You have a lot of nerve telling them I was your father.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: I couldn’t tell them you were my mother.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Of course you couldn’t. I’ve never even been married... Big laughs - the audience are loving it.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: What have you got there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19 Stan and Ollie - Blue Revisions 24.03.17 28

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: I brought you some hard boiled eggs and some nuts. HARDY looks to the audience, exasperated, and they laugh. reaction is warm and genuine, but the theatre is only hal full - there are empty seats everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Now you know I can't eat hard boiled eggs and nuts! If you wanted to bring me something why didn't you bring me a box of candy?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Well, they cost too much.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: What has that got to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: And you didn't pay me for the last box I brought you. Laughter. LAUREL offers HARDY the bag:

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Have one?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: No. I’d rather not. (To the audience, with disgust) Hard boiled eggs and nuts... LAUREL ignores him, takes an egg out and starts to peel i and eat it. HARDY watches, incredulous, as Laurel pulls a salt cellar from his pocket and sprinkles some on. INT. BACKSTAGE/STAGE, QUEEN’S HALL THEATRE, NEWCASTLE - N

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helped by BRADY and another STAGE HAND, LAUREL and HARDY who winces as he jars his knee - do a quick change into t crumpled suits and Bowler hats, ready for the finale.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: (Dismayed) What’s going on out there? All those empty seats... LAUREL, though also concerned, doesn’t respond - he nods the STAGE MANAGER.  19aA Stan and Ollie - Blue Revisions 24.03.17 28a INT. QUEEN’S HALL THEATRE, NEWCASTLE - NIGHT 19aA ‘The Dance Of The Cuckoos’ plays again, and the curtain rises. LAUREL waits for a particular note, then steps out set... but he only manages two paces before HARDY reaches and pulls him back. He goes out first in this partnership Laughter. But as HARDY strolls out self importantly, LAUR kicks him up the ass. More laughter. Finally they both wa out together to warm applause. They go into a bowing rout to the side, to the front, then towards each other - clas heads. Laughter. LAUREL sees HARDY put his hand on his kn to push himself straight again - sees a flash of pain acr his face. HARDY covers it well as he fiddles with his tie LAUREL takes his hat off and scratches his hair underneat

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for making us feel so welcome on our first night back in England. We hope you've enjoyed our bit of fun this evening - we've sure enjoyed ourselves haven't we Ollie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stan and Ollie - Pink Revisions 17.03.17 29

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: We certainly have Stanley, we've been made to feel right at home here in Newcastle, and now we’d like to finish- He gives LAUREL a brief nod of reassurance about his knee HARDY (cont'd) -with a little dance routine we like to do. Music please maestro. The tune to ‘At The Ball, That’s All’ strikes up. HARDY (cont'd) Stanley. Formally, HARDY holds his hand out and LAUREL takes it, a he were his dance partner, and they begin to perform the dance routine we saw in ‘Way Out West’. Though older and slower, they still dance beautifully, the affection their characters have for each other shining through. They come together to finish, hold hands and take a bow. They look at the half full auditorium, but still keep up their smil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL and HARDY puff and blow as they clamber up a long staircase carrying their luggage. HARDY, golf clubs again over his shoulder, drags the heavy trunk behind him.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: It was a little slow last night, wasn’t it.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Slow? We could have invited the audience back for a party in our hotel suite - there’d have been plenty of room. LAUREL smiles, HARDY is struck with a sudden thought: HARDY (cont'd) We got to be careful Muffin doesn’t come see us ‘til the houses pick up - we don’t want him getting cold feet about the movie.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: You're right. I’1l put him off ‘til we get to London... LAUREL reaches the top, rests his case, looks about for w to go next.  Stan and Ollie - Yellow Revisions 31.03.17 30 LAUREL (cont'd) (Takes out a slip of paper) Glasgow train... 8.05 Platform Four. (Looks about) Which way is Platform Four..?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: (Still struggling up the stairs) 8.05? What time is it now? LAUREL looks at his wrist - he’s not wearing a watch:

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: I don’t have my watch on. HARDY instinctively brings up his left wrist to look at h watch - but in doing so he lets go of the heavy trunk... which promptly slides away down the staircase. A moment a they both watch it trundle to the bottom and come to a st an inescapable echo of the piano famously plummeting down those long flight of stairs in their movie ‘The Music Box

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: You know one of us is going to have to get that.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: It’s me isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: It certainly is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARDY lies back in his seat, bad leg propped up, dozing. LAUREL brings back two Scotches from the buffet bar. He s them down, then resumes his seat, the remains of some sandwiches and tea in front of them. LAUREL glances at HA takes a sip from his Scotch, then nudges him.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Babe. (No response, so louder) Babe. HARDY wakes up, sees LAUREL. With a grimace of pain he si up, bringing his leg down from the seat opposite.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: I got you a drink. HARDY sees the Scotch, takes it and downs it.  Stan and Ollie - Yellow Revisions 31.03.17 30aA

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Thank you. LAUREL now hands him a few typed pages of script. HARDY l at them, confused for a moment, then takes them.  Stan and Ollie - Pink Revisions 17.03.17 30A

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: I been workin’ on some new scenes for ‘Rob ‘Em Good’, thought we could run ‘em? HARDY sees a pot of tea and some cups in front of them, p the script down and pours himself a cup. LAUREL (cont'd) We don’t have to if you don’t want to. Stan and Ollie - Locked White Shooting Script 22.02.17 3

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: No no... (Almost as an aside) I know my place. It’s a little barb he throws out but LAUREL doesn’t take With great delicacy HARDY begins a long ritual: dropping cubes of sugar in, then milk and carefully stirring, maki sure the lumps dissolve. He then spills some red tablets a bottle onto the little table in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Knee still bad? HARDY nods as he counts out four and puts the others back the bottle. LAUREL (cont'd) I thought you were on the blue tablets?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I already had the blue ones and it’s still killin’ me. I thought I'd give the red ones one more chance.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Well won’t the blue ones get upset about that?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I never thought about it.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: It’s got to be one or the other, you can’t keep both of them on the go at the same time... Finally, after one last emphatic stir, HARDY puts the fir tablet in his mouth, picks his cup up with a crooked litt finger, and takes a sip to wash it down. LAUREL (cont'd) -they’1l get jealous and start fighting over you. HARDY immediately reacts, pulls a face, but is forced to swallow.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you tell me it was cold?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: I thought you knew? HARDY looks at him, exhales in frustration, and downs the other three tablets quickly with another gulp of cold tea  21 Stan and Ollie - Green Revisions 11.04.17 32 He shudders with distaste, then picks the script up again starts to read through it. But he’s distracted, can’t concentrate. He turns to LAUREL:

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: That guy who went on stage the night before he died....

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Billy Brady?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Yeh.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Wasn’t that something, to still be working in his old age like that?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: That’s what's been bothering me. He wasn’t working, he was dying. Didn't you find it sad? As LAUREL thinks about this, HARDY takes the flask from h and has a sip.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Well... look at Jimmy Finlayson.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Nobody even knew he’d died, just lay there in his bed, all alone. He finished too soon - same cafe every morning, reading the papers, trying to make that stretch to midday so he’s only got the afternoon to kill? Who wants that? HARDY has another sip.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Maybe he was happy doing nothing. There’s an awful lot to be said for it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grey morning, the wind whipping across the Clyde. HARDY smokes a cigarette as he stands down the street from the boys’ next venue - the ‘Empire Glasgow’. Under this we he  Stan and Ollie - Blue Revisions 24.03.17 32A

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Miffin please... Yes this is Stan Laurel... Well that’s very nice of you to say so...  Stan and Ollie - Blue Revisions 24.03.17 33 Shot TRACKS to REVEAL LAUREL making another call in a pub phone box. HARDY, out of earshot, waits for him.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Mr. Hardy? Oh he’s indisposed right now- (Sees HARDY outside) -he’s working in a Swiss cheese factory. He got a job putting in the holes- (He obviously gets a laugh, listens some more) He’s in a meeting? Okay, it’s just that I need to confirm a date for him to come see us in London. (Listens) No please don’t interrupt him, I'11l try again another time. (Listens) No that’s fine... you too. He hangs up and emerges from the phone box, joins HARDY a they walk away together.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: How was Ida?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Fine. Ducks were fine... LAUREL suddenly stops and pulls out another beret from hi coat pocket and hands it to HARDY.  22 23 Stan and Ollie - Blue Revisions 24.03.17 34 LAUREL (cont'd) Here, I got you a present. HARDY takes it and, delighted, puts it on immediately (LA is already wearing his).

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: How does it look?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Swell. WIDE SHOT: the two of them walk off towards the theatre.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: We're two peas in a pod. They pass a WOMAN pushing a pram and both politely doff t berets to her.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY WOMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -yes but we just wanted to know who’s going to be playing Laurel and Hardy please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ELDERLY COUPLE are at the box office with the MANAGER:

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: They're playing themselves.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY WOMAN
dialogues.text: Who are?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Laurel and Hardy. ‘Here In Person’ the poster says - they’re here in person.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY WOMAN
dialogues.text: Yes but they’ve been retired for years. Before we buy any tickets we want to know the names of the actors who are going to be playing them here? In this actual theatre?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: (Exasperated) They are playing themselves! At this point LAUREL and HARDY walk through the foyer on their way into the theatre. They spot the ELDERLY COUPLE once more politely doff their berets:  24 Stan and Ollie - Green Revisions 11.04.17 35

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL AND HARDY
dialogues.text: (Smiling politely) Good afternoon. Out on the ELDERLY COUPLE’S astonished expressions. UNDER this we hear...

dialogues.speaker: HARDY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .-- Ladies and gentlemen, we’d like to thank you for making us feel so welcome here in Glasgow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience tonight is again, disappointingly, only half full - though they are enjoying seeing the boys resplende in kilts especially for their Scottish fans. We pick out DELFONT in the audience, looking around, noting the gaps.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Not just Glasgow, the whole of Wales. Hardy points to the kilts they are wearing LAUREL (cont'd) Why aren’t we wearing any trousers?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Because we're in Scotland.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Yes but why aren’t we wearing any trousers?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Never mind. Ladies and gentlemen we'd like to finish with a dance. Laurel throws him a knowing look - Hardy’s not well enoug do the dance number.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: No. No, you sing a song and I’1l do a dance.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Alright, have it your way. What song would you like to do?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: We'd like to perform ‘Shine on Harvey Moon’.  Stan and Ollie - Green Revisions 11.04.17 35aaA

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: ‘Shine on Harvest Moon’.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Alright, we’ll do that one then.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Maestro, may I have a ukulele?  Stan and Ollie - Blue Revisions 24.03.17 35aA HARDY starts to play on his ukulele then sings the song i his beautiful tenor voice, LAUREL harmonizing, his gentle flat voice a perfect foil. At the same time LAUREL perfor little soft shoe shuffle around the (stationary) HARDY.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL AND HARDY
dialogues.text: (Singing) Oh, Shine on, shine on, harvest moon Up in the sky... I ain't had no lovin' (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stan and Ollie - Pink Revisions 17.03.17 35A

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL AND HARDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Since January, February, June or July Snow time ain't no time to stay Outdoors and spoon Shine on, shine on, harvest moon For me and my gal... Enthusiastic applause; they go into their ‘bowing routine (ending with them banging heads in the middle). They get laughs, but we see how pale and sweaty HARDY is - the physical demands of this type of touring taking a toll.  25 Stan and Ollie - Locked White Shooting Script 22.02.17 36

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That evening. LAUREL and HARDY, glum and apprehensive aft another poorly attended show, sit in a corner booth with DELFONT, who tucks into a pub meal of sausage and mash. LAUREL and HARDY don’t eat but have pints of beer in fron them and both smoke heavily, a thick haze hanging over th booth. Nothing is said until, finally, DELFONT finishes h last mouthful and dabs vigorously at his mouth with a nap

dialogues.speaker: DELFONT
dialogues.text: Now then, gentlemen... (More dabbing, puts napkin down ) Terrific though the show is, and it really is terrific-

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: DELFONT
dialogues.text: -we really do have to have a little think about where we go from here. Sweating profusely, HARDY pours himself a glass of water the ever-present jug he has at the dinner table.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: We have new material we can work in, don’t we Stan.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: We have a double door routine we can do, set in a railway station, and as soon as Babe’s leg is better we can bring back the dance number at the end.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: It's getting better all the time.

dialogues.speaker: DELFONT
dialogues.text: Yes, I think that would all help enormously. And of course it’s early days and all that but, unfortunately, the houses have thus far been extremely disappointing.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: But that’s because we’re playing in all these little theatres.

dialogues.speaker: DELFONT
dialogues.text: Yes and I’m absolutely furious about that. Stan and Ollie - Locked White Shooting Script 22.02.17 3

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: But you booked us in them? What happened to the big ones we played last time we were over?

dialogues.speaker: DELFONT
dialogues.text: Well we couldn’t be sure how ticket sales would go you see, and- LAUREL, suddenly getting it, looks thunderstruck.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, wait a minute... you want to close us down?

dialogues.speaker: DELFONT
dialogues.text: Absolutely not. That’s the last thing I want to do.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: We haven’t even done a week!

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: When do you want us to finish?

dialogues.speaker: DELFONT
dialogues.text: I thought it would be best if we wrapped it up before you got to London?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: What!

dialogues.speaker: DELFONT
dialogues.text: That would give us another ten shows or so. With a bit of a push - ‘last shows’, that sort of thing - and the advance bookings we already have, we should just about be able to wash our hands.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: But the producer of the movie’s coming to see the show in London next month, isn’t he Stan?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: And Lucille and Ida are coming over in a couple of weeks - we can’t finish early.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: We made it perfectly clear- (Grasps at the figure) -one hundred and ten per cent clear, that the only reason we came over for this tour was to be available for that movie.  Stan and Ollie - Blue Revisions 24.03.17 38 DELFONT looks at them both, considering the situation.

dialogues.speaker: DELFONT
dialogues.text: I thought you'd jump at the chance. Neither of you looks particularly well?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I'm in perfect health.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: And so is he.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Mr Delfont, we need this tour to continue.

dialogues.speaker: DELFONT
dialogues.text: And of course I’m enormously sympathetic. Enormously. But your audience doesn’t quite seem to be what it was, and advance bookings are very slow. It’s a wonderful show, very charming and sweet, but perhaps... tastes have changed? All good things must come to an end, that sort of thing?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: We can turn it around.

dialogues.speaker: DELFONT
dialogues.text: The public moves on. So many don’t even come to the theatre now, just stay at home watching their television sets... watching your films on their television sets, come to think of it - and you not even getting any residuals. (Shakes his head and tuts) Filthy business.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Just tell us what you want us to do and we’ll do it. DELFONT looks from HARDY, who wipes the sweat from his forehead with a napkin, to LAUREL, who looks at him expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: DELFONT
dialogues.text: Well... if you really want to keep this tour going, then all I can think of... is you’re going to have to get out there and publicize it. (He looks at them both) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stan and Ollie - Pink Revisions 17.03.17 38A

dialogues.speaker: DELFONT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Which would mean a very large amount of extra work for you both, making personal appearances, opening shops, meeting local dignitaries and so on and so forth. And for, broadly speaking, very little extra money.  26 Stan and Ollie - Locked White Shooting Script 22.02.17 39

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: I take it that ‘very little’ actually means no extra money at all?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: That we would have to flog ourselves half to death for nothing?

dialogues.speaker: DELFONT
dialogues.text: Well... (Sees in their eyes that there’s no point lying) Yes. LAUREL and HARDY exchange. A beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Well okay.

dialogues.speaker: DELFONT
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: We’ll do it. DELFONT is taken aback by how upbeat and defiant they see

dialogues.text: BLACK AND WHITE NEWSREEL FOOTAGE: On a freezing cold day, good-sized crowd has gathered to watch LAUREL and HARDY p for some shots with local PRESS PHOTOGRAPHERS. The boys a wearing uniforms of white overalls and black peaked caps scarves wrapped round their necks to keep them warm, and are surrounded by young SCHOOL CHILDREN.

dialogues.text: Taking time out from a nationwide tour of music halls - tickets still available - Messrs. Laurel and Hardy were in Merthyr Tydfil this week for to lend their support to a new road safety programme.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREEL COMMENTARY
dialogues.text: On a bitterly cold day the boys had luckily come prepared.  27 28 Stan and Ollie - Green Revisions 11.04.17 40 As the CHILDREN cross HARDY stamps his feet and blows his hands to keep warm. Meanwhile LAUREL pulls a hot water bo from inside his coat and a cup from his pocket then - to laughs - pours some tea into it from the hot water bottle HARDY rolls his eyes in exasperation - then suddenly noti that Laurel’s sign is bigger than his. dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A steam train thunders across country; underneath this a 1950s vintage graphic shows the progress of the tour, fro Glasgow to Manchester, Liverpool, and then finally starti to head south, to Nottingham, Leicester, Birmingham..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL is stood next to HARDY’S bed, his arm resting on t iron headboard. But, unknown to LAUREL his arm is looped through the rope holding up HARDY’S leg.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: If you really want to help me, why don’t you get me a nice glass of water. LAUREL turns round to the bed side table but in doing so pulls HARDY’S leg up even higher and the counterweight la on HARDY’S head. HARDY lets out an ‘oohhh’. LAUREL quickl turns back to HARDY.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: What’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: My head hurts.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: I’1ll get the doctor. LAUREL again turns around, lifting HARDY’S leg and landin the counterweight on his head. HARDY lets out another ‘oohhh’. LAUREL turns back to HARDY again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 30 Stan and Ollie - Green Revisions 11.04.17 40aA

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Never mind the doctor, just get me my glass of water. LAUREL turns around for a third time to get the glass of water, but this time HARDY pushes his leg down hard quick pulling LAUREL back round to face him and accidentally throwing the glass of water all over HARDY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Various shots of posters being pasted up outside theatres see the poster headings - ‘Hippodrome Birmingham’; ‘Alham Bradford’; ‘Palace Hull’...

The boys each hold bags o chips, then HARDY is handed a bottle of vinegar by the ch shop owner. He starts to sprinkle vinegar on his chips bu allows himself to be ‘distracted’ and turns away to one s smiling to fans, and doesn’t see LAUREL put his bag of ch over Hardy’s so he gets all the vinegar instead. dialogues.text: + eH  31 Stan and Ollie - Pink Revisions 17.03.17 40A

HARDY looks pale and - frankly - exhaust  32 33 34 35 36 37 Stan and Ollie - Green Revisions 11.04.17 41 He’s wobbly on the steps with his bad knee but once he’s safely on the platform he also turns and waves to the fan The boys then go into their bowing routine: to each side, the front, then to each other - banging heads. Big laughs

dialogues.text: Another PA - PHOTOGRAPHERS snap away as LAUREL and HARDY, each with a conductor’s ticket machine strapped to his ch Manually wind out tickets from their machines for PASSENG boarding a trolley-bus. dialogues.text: An express sleeper, the engine’s headlamp illuminating sw of steam as, even at night, the boys keep on moving, movi The graphic map shows the tour stopping at Cardiff, then Bristol, then Exeter before reaching Plymouth. END MONTAG INT. HER MAJESTY’S THEATRE, PLYMOUTH - NIGHT 37

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the hard work leads to here. HARDY sits on a bench in unfamiliar set - a railway platform - looking at his watc impatiently. The auditorium is jam-packed full; the audie spread across all ages - happy, expectant. On stage HARDY can wait no more, gets up and exits throug door into the waiting room. At this exact moment LAUREL c out onto the stage through another door next to the first door. LOUD APPLAUSE as he looks around, puzzled, for Hard  Stan and Ollie - Pink Revisions 17.03.17 41A LAUREL checks his watch, then decides to go and look for but once again at the precise moment he exits through his door HARDY enters through the other one. BIG LAUGHS.  38 Stan and Ollie - Goldenrod Revisions 20.04.17 42 The sketch builds through multiple exits and entrances, t split second timing impeccable, their reactions and expressions supremely skilful. As the sketch continues th laughter builds, the audience loving what they see. At on point they both exit the stage, then enter together. The CHILDREN in the audience are HOWLING, but LAUREL and HARD ‘don’t notice’ each other, turning in the wrong direction look for each other and exiting together. A moment, then enter again and walk smack bang into each other - bringin the house down. The audience is on it’s feet APPLAUSE, CH and CRIES ringing down. They beam in appreciation, blowin kisses as the curtain falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As LAUREL and HARDY come offstage to huge applause, dripp with sweat, they turn to each other and from their expressions they know that tonight has gone well. Really well. DELFONT is in the wings waiting for them.

dialogues.speaker: DELFONT
dialogues.text: Gentlemen - we’re back in business! Well done, well done - we’ve turned it around! I never doubted we would...

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Your faith sustained us.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Our wives arrive next week Mr. Delfont, we’d sure like to still have a show when they get here.

dialogues.speaker: DELFONT
dialogues.text: Not only will you still have a show, but it will be playing in London!

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: For real?

dialogues.speaker: DELFONT
dialogues.text: The Lyceum was free so I have booked a two week run, beginning a week on Sunday. kk

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: (Delighted) The Lyceum? ** DELFONT shakes both of their hands, vigorously.

dialogues.speaker: DELFONT
dialogues.text: Hearty felicitations - we must celebrate!  39 Stan and Ollie - Locked White Shooting Script 22.02.17 43 He snaps his fingers and a STAGE HAND brings over a tray two glasses of champagne on it; DELFONT hands them out.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: (Taking his) Thank you very much, our wives will be delighted. How about dinner tonight, on us?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: (Taking his) That’s a good idea. I’m having steak. A big, thick juicy steak smothered with onions.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: I’m having the same as he’s having. Except I want fish. And no onions.

dialogues.speaker: DELFONT
dialogues.text: (Smiling thinly) Ha - yes let’s do that. Can’t make it tonight I’ve said I'll say hello to Danny Kaye after his show - huge fan of yours of course. But we must celebrate. We’1ll talk anon! He leaves. On LAUREL and HARDY watching him go. A beat, t they turn to each other and HARDY holds up his glass:

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: To us. LAUREL smiles, and clinks his glass against Hardy's.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Bottoms up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL and HARDY read from scripts as they rehearse some lines from the movie.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: You're on the log with Robin Hood and he asks what it is you want to see him about, and you say:

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: (As ‘Friar Hardy’) We're going to give him a piece of my mind, aren't we Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: (As ‘Stanley-A-Dale’ ) We sure are.  Stan and Ollie - Pink Revisions 17.03.17 44

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: (As ‘Friar Hardy’) We'd give him a piece of his too, but he doesn’t have any to spare. HARDY smiles at this, comes out of character. HARDY (cont'd) Yeh, that’s a nice line. (Beat, thoughtful) Is this movie happening Stan?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: (Taken off guard) Yes. Of course it is. Why d’you ask that?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Oh... it’s just that Lucille will ask me about it, and I know you've been struggling to get through to Muff- (He remembers ) -Miffin.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: I'm meeting him next week, it’s all lined up.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I mean, I’m enjoying how the show’s going, but... it’s the movie we’re doing this for isn’t it.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: That's right - and then one thing leads to another.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Because we can’t keep touring like this forever, can we. Before LAUREL can answer, a GUARD walks past their compartment, calling out to passengers:

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: London terminus, next and final stop. They look at each other, then get up, excitedly. They go into the corridor and pull down the window on the door so they can lean outside. It’s a bit of a squeeze, but - hai blowing in the wind - they can see the unmistakable Londo skyline fast approaching. With excited faces they shake hands, delighted to have made it to the capital.  40 4l 42 43 Stan and Ollie - Pink Revisions 17.03.17 45

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next morning, LAUREL exits the hotel dressed in unfamilia business attire (smart overcoat and Homburg hat), smiling nodding to the BELL BOYS. He takes in the air, full of en and expectation, then strolls off down the Strand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taxis and red buses weave past, with adverts for Bovril, Players cigarettes and Schweppes on the side. Men in hats ladies in heels bustle along this busy corner of the west end. LAUREL walks along, (to where we don’t yet know), th pauses to study a poster outside a cinema: ‘Abbott & Cost Go To Mars’. The blurb tells us they are ‘Hollywood’s No. Comedy Duo’. This is the double act that has effectively replaced Laurel & Hardy in the affections of modern moviegoers. LAUREL looks at their young faces, the silver space suits, the shiny rocket, the future... A MAN walks up and stands next to him, also to look at th poster. A few moments then LAUREL, aware of the MAN stand on his shoulder, turns to look at him. At the same time t MAN turns to LAUREL and gives him a polite smile. LAUREL to smile back but realises the MAN is tremendously boss-e his eyes literally looking in opposite directions. LAUREL double takes. The MAN politely raises his hat, then walks away. OUT on LAUREL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing his beret, a smiling HARDY - full of the joys of - strolls down the street singing softly to himself, humm some of the words he can’t quite bring to mind:

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: (Singing) Let me call you Sweetheart, I'm in love with you Let me hear you whisper that you love me too Keep the da-da hmm hmm in your eyes so true Let me call you Sweetheart, I'm in love with you... He passes a little florist’s stall outside the tube stati is about to go down the stairs when he decides he’s feeli so good he wants a buttonhole. He selects a red carnation and, with great delicacy, pulls a shilling from his walle pay for it. Back to the song, he hums and whistles as he carries on jauntily into the tube station, pinning the carnation to his lapel as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WEST END
dialogues.text: LAUREL strides up to a building with brass business plate outside, checks the address against a slip of paper, ente  Stan and Ollie - Pink Revisions 17.03.17 45A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL removes his hat and approaches the RECEPTIONIST, a insipid-type, mid-20s.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: I’m here to see Mr. Miffin.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: And your name please?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Mr. Laurel. She starts to write everything down.  45 46 Stan and Ollie - Pink Revisions 17.03.17 46

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Do you have an appointment Mr. Lauren? He doesn’t pick her up on mispronouncing his name.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: We keep missing each other on the telephone so I thought if I dropped by that would be the easiest thing.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Because he’s not here right now.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: (Beat, thinks about this) That’s okay, I can wait. I think I've been speaking to another girl on the telephone about this - I’ve been speaking to her for a while?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: She’s left. Are you sure you want to wait? He may be quite a while?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Well, I’m here now aren’t I.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Take a seat over there Mr. Lauren- (Indicates a row of chairs) -I'll let his office know you’re here. He still doesn’t pick her up on the name thing. As she ma an internal call he sits down. He looks over to a door at far end of the reception area. Another closed door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tray of diamond bracelets are removed from a shop windo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tray is set down by a (male) ASSISTANT in front of HA The ASSISTANT indicates a bracelet in the middle of the t

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: A beautiful piece sir. HARDY looks at it, but his eye is taken by one above it w is much, much classier with alternating diamonds and rubi

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Mr. Laurel not with you today? HARDY, preoccupied, answers without looking up:  Stan and Ollie - Pink Revisions 17.03.17 46A

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Oh he’s just got himself a new job, mending broken biscuits. The ASSISTANT laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: I think it’s wonderful you're still going.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Rigor mortis hasn’t set in just yet- He points to the expensive bracelet.  47 48 Stan and Ollie - Pink Revisions 17.03.17 47 HARDY (cont'd) -I’'m very taken with this one? The ASSISTANT takes it from the tray and lays it out ona small patch of velvet cloth.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: One of our best pieces, diamonds and rubies set in a gold bracelet.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: My wife’s arriving from overseas today and it’s a gift, you see.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: It’s the most expensive item on the tray. One hundred and fifty pounds. HARDY smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Pardon me for just a moment. He takes his wallet from his back pocket, turns away from ASSISTANT, opens it and counts through the notes inside w his fingers. He doesn’t have enough. Not nearly. A though frown for a moment, then he turns back to the ASSISTANT: HARDY (cont'd) I wonder if you could just hold it for me and I’1l be right back with the full amount... (Motions ‘hurrying feet’ with his fingers) -..‘tout suite’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL, patient as ever, is still being kept waiting. He catches the eye of the RECEPTIONIST and gives her a famil ruffle of his hair into a mad quiff. But this produces no response - she simply thinks him rather odd. So he tries something else: putting his hat back on, he puts his fing in his mouth and blows it like it’s a valve. He can see t RECEPTIONIST trying not to look, but finding herself wondering what on earth he’s doing. He puts his finger in again and blows harder; by leaning the brim of his hat ba slightly against the wall behind him, he makes it look as his hat is lifting off his head. She watches this, but there’s still no laugh - she just looks vaguely uncomfortable, embarrassed even. LAUREL gives up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARDY is in a public phone box making a call. The pips go he inserts a coin to connect.  49 Stan and Ollie - Blue Revisions 24.03.17 48

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Concierge please... (Waits) Hello? Raymond..? (Listens) Ray it’s Mr. Hardy from room 430- (Listens) -I’m very well thank you - now that discussion the other day about our four-legged friends... (Listens) Yes I wonder if you could speak to your man and place a bet for me... He puts the phone in the crook of his neck, pulls out his wallet, and takes out a slip of paper with a name and mee scribbled on it: HARDY (cont'd) «+. it’s Hometown Boy, in the 2.30 at Kempton. Five to one shot. As he listens he opens his wallet again and counts with h fingers five of the ten pounds notes in there (leaving another tenner and a fiver). HARDY (cont'd) Fifty. (Fingers the last tenner and the fiver) +. let’s make that sixty. (Amount repeated to him) Yes sixty. On the nose. (Listens) Thank you so much. Yes, tally-ho to you too. He hangs up and nods to himself, confident, certain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL is fixated on the closed door. Something snaps and gets up and walks over to it. As he passes the RECEPTIONI

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Hello? Can I help you? He ignores her, goes up to the door and knocks. RECEPTIONIST (cont'd) I have asked you to wait... LAUREL knocks again. RECEPTIONIST (cont'd) -please you’re not allowed in there- LAUREL grips the handle, opens the door and strides into.  50 Stan and Ollie - Pink Revisions 17.03.17 49 INT. MIFFIN’S OFFICE - DAY 50 -+. an empty office. Desk and chair, leather sofa facing; posters from various low budget British movies from the 4 and 50s on the walls. He looks around. Empty. From behind

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA, (OOV)
dialogues.text: You’re here to see Mr. Miffin? He turns round, sees CYNTHIA, 50s, glasses, a formidable- looking production executive, standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Yes. Sorry, I... Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: I’m his production executive, Cynthia Clarke.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Hello Cynthia.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Mr. Miffin is still detained, but I’ve just spoken to him on the telephone and he wanted me to explain the situation to you. (LAUREL swallows) He says he’s sorry, but he’s been unable to raise the finance needed to proceed with the film.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: (Beat) Oh... I see.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: He said he made it clear in a cable he sent to you before you left the United States, that all the finance wasn’t in place?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Yes but I thought he’d have it all lined up by now.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: He wanted you to know that he did everything he could to bring the project together, but he feels sure you'll understand that the market is very challenging at the moment, and that it just wasn’t possible. LAUREL looks at her, crushed, as the enormity of what she saying now starting to sink in. But he remains polite.  51 52 Stan and Ollie - Pink Revisions 17.03.17 50

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Yes. Thank you. Thank you very much for your time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARDY - in coat and beret, cigarette hanging from his lip hurries out of the tube station and makes for a newspaper vendor who is opening some bales of freshly-arrived eveni papers. He pays for one, feverishly turns to the racing p and scans the ‘Stop Press’. He finds his race, and... he’ lost. We see his bitter disappointment. He screws the pap up and is about to angrily hurl it into a litter bin when sees some SCHOOL KIDS, in uniform, staring at him shyly. beat, then he forces a smile, calmly drops the paper in t bin and flutters his tie at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late afternoon now. LAUREL and HARDY, each glum for diffe reasons, smoke cigarettes as they wait outside the hotel the taxi rank. The boys savour deep puffs, as if their la HARDY’S attention is caught by a NEWSREEL CREW setting up cover the entrance. He looks puzzled...

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Delfont’s idea, thought the girls arriving would be a good excuse for some free publicity. (Beat) I’m sure lookin’ forward to seeing them again.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I been countin’ the days.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Forty six. (HARDY looks at him, puzzled) Since we got here. Forty six days. (HARDY still puzzled) I thought you said you been countin’ them?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I just meant the last few. Seven or eight.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Not forty six. Who counts from forty six? LAUREL shrugs, blankly. Stan and Ollie - Locked White Shooting Script 22.02.17 5

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: You know, I been thinking... they don’t need to know about everything we been doing, do they? Like, for instance, all the personal appearances...

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: No sense in getting them all worked up.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: In a way, it’s a kindness keeping them in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: It certainly is.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Well that’s settled. We’1l just talk about how well the tour’s going. (Afterthought) And the movie. LAUREL can't bring himself to break it to Hardy - not yet

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Yeh. The movie. LAUREL takes another deep puff on his cigarette. He glanc over to the MOVIETONE CREW and an idea forms: LAUREL (cont'd) Hey, if the car pulls up there- (Indicates in front of them) -maybe we can do the door thing?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Will you give it a rest Stan? A limousine sweeps up to the front of the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Here they are! Like naughty schoolboys LAUREL and HARDY quickly throw th cigarettes away; the PHOTOGRAPHERS and NEWSREEL CREW spri into action. As the car pulls up in front of them LAUREL gives HARDY a look and he reluctantly nods, ‘okay’. He go to the side of the car nearest the wall and from there op the rear door whilst LAUREL goes to the other side of the and opens that. LAUREL leans in and in the back are LUCIL HARDY, a pretty, unfussy Southern belle, 40s, and Laurel’ wife IDA, same age glamorously dressed, of Russian descen He gives IDA a kiss:  53 Stan and Ollie - Locked White Shooting Script 22.02.17 52 LAUREL (cont'd) Hiya sweetie pie. Girls, can you both get out this side - I got something I want to do.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: (Thick Russian accent) Of course dahling, where do you want me? I give them my good side. LUCILLE isn’t as thrilled at the idea of a bit of ‘busine after her long journey-

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Oh no Stanley... we just got here? -but she follows them out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACK AND WHITE NEWSREEL FOOTAGE: LAUREL leads IDA and LUCILLE around the back of the limousine to HARDY’S side, where their progress is blocked by his open door.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREEL COMMENTARY
dialogues.text: Comedy duo Laurel and Hardy were joined in London this week by their wives. But even in a simple situation like this, trouble just seems to follow them around. LAUREL feigns ‘confusion’. What does he do now? We...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: HARDY waits by the door, with his back to LAUREL and the GIRLS, wondering where they are. NEWSREEL COMMENTARY (cont'd) Oliver Hardy, Bachelor of Arts, always seems to have the situation under control... but somehow things never seem to work out that way.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: LAUREL now leads the girls back round to the other side o the limousine, takes them through the driver’s compartmen and out Hardy’s side, where HARDY ‘jumps’ in surprise and gives the GIRLS a coy flutter of his tie in greeting. The couples hold hands and enter the hotel together, stopping the entrance for a cheery wave to camera. NEWSREEL COMMENTARY (cont'd) Yes they’re reunited again, and now everyone can start making up for lost time.  Stan and Ollie - Blue Revisions 24.03.17 53 For the camera HARDY takes LUCILLE’S hand and kisses it, does the same to IDA. LAUREL kisses IDA’S hand then LUCILLE’S, and finally LAUREL offers HARDY his hand and H kisses that too - before slapping it away in ‘distaste’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two COUPLES enter the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Did they get all that okay?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: It was fine, it'll get a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: (Sarcastic) Well I’m awfully glad about that I’m sure, but it would have been nice to say hello to my husband after eight weeks without immediately being pressed into one of your skits Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: It was just small funny.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Is that what it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LAURELS and HARDYS dine together, IDA and LUCILLE tak the opportunity to both dress glamorously.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Can't we visit the Tower Of London? And Saint Paul’s. And Harrods.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: And Buckingham Palace, where that darling new queen lives.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Of course my angel, you can visit wherever you like.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Winter Palace at St. Petersburg, this is Palace. Buckingham is little dog house.  Stan and Ollie - Pink Revisions 17.03.17 54

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: To think of her in there, with all those rooms, and the soldiers outside looking after her. Isn't she’s just the sweetest little doll?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: What about if we knock on the door and ask for a cup of sugar?

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Don’t you dare! But then she laughs when she realises LAUREL is just kidd

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: You know, we been counting the days ‘til you got here. All forty six of them.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Oh Oliver, that is the sweetest thing. HARDY can’t look at LAUREL. He busies himself sprinkling salt on his food. LUCILLE (cont'd) How’s the movie coming along Stanley?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: It’s all set up, for when we finish the tour.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: The producer is this fellow called Muffin, and Stan’s re-written the script for him, and then-

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Oliver that’s enough salt. HARDY immediately stops. LUCILLE (cont'd) You know it’s bad for your blood pressure.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Sorry honey, just force of habit. Anyway, the producer’s going to come and watch the show next week isn’t that right Stan?  Stan and Ollie - Yellow Revisions 31.03.17 55

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Yeh, he said he’d try and get along. LUCILLE wonders about this response. Why is he only going ‘try’ to see them?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: And Stan's been looking after me wonderfully, making sure daddy takes all his tablets. He kisses the ends of his fingers and blows them to her, he always does.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Has he been taking the blue ones Stanley?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: Blue? I been giving him green ones.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Green! Oh my goodness what are they? She looks at HARDY, worried. He just smiles nervously.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: He’s just kidding.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: (quietly to herself) I’m not finding that funny. HARDY secretly glares at LAUREL - not the time or place t joke! Suddenly, IDA announces:

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: I was dancer. I dance for Preston Sturges I dance for Harold Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: (Rolling her eyes) Really Ida? You’ve never mentioned this before?

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: When my knee hurt, I dance some more, I go faster, I jump high - and the hurt go away. I forget pain. Pain is only in your mind Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: It’s not in his mind Ida, it’s in his knee. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stan and Ollie - Yellow Revisions 31.03.17 55A

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And there’s no way Stanley, that he can do the scene in this movie where he falls into the river. LAUREL shoots a glance to HARDY, who looks embarrassed.  Stan and Ollie - Yellow Revisions 31.03.17

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I was telling her about the script...

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: They can use double?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: That’s what I told her.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Preston Sturges use double.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: And it’s okay for him to sit about in a river all day is it, catching his death of cold? Honestly Stanley...

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Why you keep say Stanley?

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Anyway, show must go on. And don’t worry about river jump, it’s easy as cake.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Easy as pie.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: It’s a piece of cake.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: That’s what’s I say. 56 LUCILLE thinks about biting back, but decides against it. places her cutlery on her plate, finished.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Well, I’m ready for an early night. I’m pooped. And I don’t suppose it’ll do you boys any harm either - goodness knows what you’ve been getting up to while we were away.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: (Wagging finger at LAUREL) Yes. If I find out you been drinking and smoking oh boy, you in big trouble. They both try to look innocent and offended.  56 Stan and Ollie - Yellow Revisions 31.03.17 56A INT. HARDY’S SAVOY HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT 56

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back up in their room, LUCILLE is busy arranging flowers a huge bunch Hardy has bought her, into a vase.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Oh Oliver they’re lovely, you really know how to spoil me. She looks to HARDY, who is lying on the bed watching her. LUCILLE (cont'd) I was so worried you were going to go out and buy me something we couldn’t afford.  Stan and Ollie - Blue Revisions 24.03.17 57

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: In future I am only buying you things I don’t have enough money for. He tries to joke about it, but she can see he’s downcast. goes over to the bed, sits next to him.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: You don’t have to buy me anything, you're everything I could ever want. LUCILLE takes off her dressing gown and gets in bed with HARDY, who cuddles up to her, arms around her.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: This is what I’ve been waiting for. LUCILLE smiles, squeezes his arm contentedly. HARDY (cont'd) Why are you interested in a fat old man like me? This is clearly an old joke between them.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Hey you, that’s my husband you’re talking about. I love you and you can’t stop me. LUCILLE shuts her eyes and tries to relax.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: How was the trip over with Ida?

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: You know Ida, exhausting. When she gets something in her head she won't let it go ‘til she’s worried it to death, and God forbid anyone should raise the slightest criticism of Stanley. Hardy laughs. LUCILLE (cont'd) Has he been pushing you too hard Babe?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: (Tired sigh) Well, it’s more difficult than I first thought. HARDY closes his eyes. She looks at him, worried how hard he’s pushing himself. She strokes his forehead.  Stan and Ollie - Blue Revisions 24.03.17 57A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL finishes making an order at the hotel bar and come back to sit with IDA at a table.  Stan and Ollie - Blue Revisions 24.03.17 58

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Oliver is like cat on hot roof with Lucille. She wear pants in Hardy house.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: He’s been like that with all his wives. Jumps around after them the whole time, trying to please them.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: You can learn this. LAUREL smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: But she’s been good for him, considering the state he was in. (Thinks about this) That we were both in. (Turns to IDA) But now we don’t smoke and we don’t drink and we’re much happier.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: He should say ‘thank you’ to you, for all you do for him. You could have said long time ago, ‘goodbye Oliver’.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: That’s all in the past, where it should stay. A WAITER brings them over cups of coffee each and also pl a Scotch in front of LAUREL. LAUREL (cont'd) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Are you crazy! Take it back.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: (To WAITER) It’s okay. (To IDA) I’m not going to drink it... LAUREL holds the tumbler up to his nose: LAUREL (cont'd) I just wanted to smell it. LAUREL breathes in the aroma of the Scotch  58 59 60 Stan and Ollie - Yellow Revisions 31.03.17 59

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Bad for diabetes. But LAUREL continues to toy with it. Annoyed, IDA snatche from him and downs it in one. IDA (cont'd) Now you can’t drink. (Beat) I don’t want to lose you Stanley. He puckers up and she gives him a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: And nobody even knows you’re really a man. She gives him a weary smile and a little shove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To establish the boys’ opening night in London, their nam up in lights outside the iconic London Palladium, the country’s premier theatre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Backstage, almost ready to start the show. HARDY paces ab nervous. LAUREL, checking the paper clips on his cuffs, p out through a crack and this time sees the auditorium is packed. He allows himself a smile. He checks - no heels o his boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DELFONT, all hand-squeezes and big smiles, takes his seat next to LUCILLE and IDA just in time for the start. He lo about, very happy.

dialogues.speaker: DELFONT
dialogues.text: A sell out! The house lights dim and the orchestra strikes up ‘The Da Of The Cuckoos’. LAUREL walks out on stage followed by HARDY. HARDY turns, looking to the applauding audience, but LAUREL continues the wings on the other side of the stage. HARDY gestures him to come back onto the stage. LAUREL slowly walks out, pretending to argue with someone in the wings.  Stan and Ollie - Yellow Revisions 31.03.17 59A A lone guitarist picks out the intro to ‘Trail Of The Lonesome Pine’. The BOYS sing together in harmony:

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
